soc_scenario.description: Varying direct human influences in the historical period.
soc_scenario.description_note: Please label your model run `histsoc` **even if** it only partly accounts for varying direct human forcings while another part of the the direct human forcing is considered constant or is ignored.

datasets.comment: HYDE-based irrigated and rainfed cropland downscaled to up to 15 crops, managed pasture and grassland, urban areas. The data originates from the historic [LUH v2h Harmonization Data Set](https://luh.umd.edu) (see [Hurtt et al. 2011](https://doi.org/10.1007/s10584-011-0153-2); [Hurtt et al. 2020](https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-13-5425-2020)) and the Monfreda data set ([Monfreda et al, 2008](https://doi.org/10.1029/2007GB002947)).

Historical annual country-level wood harvesting data based on the [LUH v2h Harmonization Data Set](https://luh.umd.edu) (see [Hurtt et al. 2011](https://doi.org/10.1007/s10584-011-0153-2); [Hurtt et al. 2020](https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-13-5425-2020)).

Historical annual land-use transformation data, based on the [LUH v2h Harmonization Data Set](https://luh.umd.edu) (see [Hurtt et al. 2011](https://doi.org/10.1007/s10584-011-0153-2); [Hurtt et al. 2020](https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-13-5425-2020)).

Historical annual fertilization rates, based on the [LUH v2h Harmonization Data Set](https://luh.umd.edu) (see [Hurtt et al. 2011](https://doi.org/10.1007/s10584-011-0153-2); [Hurtt et al. 2020](https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-13-5425-2020)).
NHx and NOy deposition simulated by NCAR Chemistry-Climate Model Initiative (CCMI), see [Tian et al., 2018](https://doi.org/10.48364/ISIMIP.759077.1).
Observation-based representation of recent average planting and maturity dates not accounting for changes over time ([Jägermeyr et al. 2021](https://www.nature.com/articles/s43016-021-00400-y)).
Adopted from [Rousseau et al. (2019)](https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1820344116).

The data is based on [Lehner et al. (2011a)](https://doi.org/10.7927/H4N877QK), [Lehner et al. (2011b)](https://doi.org/10.1890/100125), and Jida Wang et al. (KSU/Kansas State University, personal communication, data starting in 2016). Because the data from KSU is yet unpublished, modeling teams using it are asked to offer co-authorship to the team at KSU on any resulting publications.

For modelling groups that do not have their own representation, we provide files containing the multi-model mean of domestic and industrial water withdrawal and consumption generated by the WaterGAP, PCR-GLOBWB, and H08 models (1850-202118). This data is based on ISIMIP2a varsoc simulations for 1901-2005, and on RCP6.0 simulations from the Water Futures and Solutions project ([Wada et al., 2016](https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-9-175-2016)) for after 2005. Years before 1901 have been filled with the value for year 1901.

Lake and reservoir area fraction/percentage calculated from the Hydrolakes v1.0 June 2019 ([Messager et al., 2016](https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms13603)) and GRanDv1.3 databases ([Lehner et al., 2011](https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1890/100125))
Observed stem numbers, thinning type, planting numbers from and common management practices for 9 forest sites in Europe from [Reyer et al. (2020)](https://doi.org/10.5194/essd-12-1295-2020).

National and gridded historical population data. Estimates are available for total as well as urban and rural population counts. The population data are adopted from HYDE v3.3 (private communication with K. Klein Goldewijk, to be published).
Based on the [World Development Indicator database (WDI)](https://databank.worldbank.org/source/world-development-indicators).

soc_scenario.description: Fixed year-1901 direct human influences (e.g. land use, nitrogen deposition and fertilizer input, fishing effort).
soc_scenario.description_note: Please only label your model run `1901soc` if it does not at all account for historical changes in direct human forcing, but they do represent constant year-1901 levels of direct human forcing for at least some direct human forcings. This scenario may be thought of an approximation of pre-industrial levels of human impacts.

soc_scenario.description: Fixed year-2015 direct human influences (e.g. land use, nitrogen deposition and fertilizer input, fishing effort).
soc_scenario.description_note: Please label your simulations `2015soc` if they do not at all account for historical changes in direct human forcing, but they do represent constant year-2015 levels of direct human forcing for at least some direct human forcings.

Please only label your model run `nat` if it does not at all account for any direct human forcings, including e.g. human land use or fishing. For Nitrogen deposition please use 1850soc values or specify which other preindustrial value you used in the model documentation.

sens_scenario.description: For all experiments other than the sensitivity experiments.
CO₂ concentration fixed at 1901 levels as a deviation from the “obsclim” climate + CO₂ forcing.
No water management (e.g. no human water abstraction, no reservoirs) while other direct human forcings such as land use changes are considered according to histsoc or 2015soc.
Simulation with fire switched off to identify impact of fire within the model.
For fisheries and marine ecosystems sector. JRA55 driven GFDL-MOM6-COBALT2 ocean climate with constant riverine nutrient and freshwater influx.
sens_scenario.description_note: Climate forcing to be taken from the `ctrlclim` inputs.

sens_scenario.description: Observed climate forcing using 30arcsec resolution used for sensitivity runs to determine the best spatial resolution of climate input data for impact models.
Observed climate forcing using 90arcsec resolution used for sensitivity runs to determine the best spatial resolution of climate input data for impact models.
Observed climate forcing using 300arcsec resolution used for sensitivity runs to determine the best spatial resolution of climate input data for impact models.
Observed climate forcing using 1800arcsec resolution used for sensitivity runs to determine the best spatial resolution of climate input data for impact models.
For fisheries and marine ecosystems sectors. Low resolution sensitivity experiment. JRA55 driven GFDL-MOM6-COBALT2 ocean climate on one degree spatial resolution.

datasets.comment: Factual climate input datasets: GSWP3-W5E5, 20CRv3-W5E5, 20CRv3-ERA5, 20CRv3.

Tracks from IBTrACS database ([Knapp et al. 2010](https://doi.org/10.1175/2009BAMS2755.1)) (period 1841-2021), Windfields calculated by Holland model ([Holland 1980](https://doi.org/10.1175/1520-0493(1980)108%3C1212:AAMOTW%3E2.0.CO;2), [Holland 2008](https://doi.org/10.1175/2008MWR2395.1)).
Flash Rate Monthly Climatology from [Cecil (2006)](https://doi.org/10.5067/LIS/LIS-OTD/DATA303).
GFDL MOM6/COBALTv2 simulations driven by reanalysis-based atmospheric forcing ([Liu et al., 2021](https://doi.org/10.1029/2021GL094367)).
Hourly coastal water levels with long-term trends for impact attribution.
1850-2005: [Meinshausen et al. (2011)](https://doi.org/10.1007/s10584-011-0156-z), 2006-2021: [Dlugokencky & Tans (2022)](https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/trends/)
1850-2014: [Meinshausen et al. (2017)](https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-10-2057-2017), 2015-2021: [Dlugokencky (2022)](https://gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/trends_ch4/)
Detrended versions of the GSWP3-W5E5, 20CRv3-W5E5, 20CRv3-ERA5, 20CRv3 data sets derived by the Attrici method.

We do not provide "no climate change" TC tracks and windfields but the original tracks from the IBTrACS database ([Knapp et al. 2010](https://doi.org/10.1175/2009BAMS2755.1)) (period 1841-2021) windfields calculated by Holland model ([Holland 1980](https://doi.org/10.1175/1520-0493(1980)108%3C1212:AAMOTW%3E2.0.CO;2), [Holland 2008](https://doi.org/10.1175/2008MWR2395.1)) should be used in combination with the counterfactual water levels to estimate the impacts of sea level rise on TC induced damages, losses or replacement.

We do not provide "no climate change" lightning data. Instead the original Flash Rate Monthly Climatology from [Cecil (2006)](https://doi.org/10.5067/LIS/LIS-OTD/DATA303) should be used in the **counterclim** set-up.
We do not provide any counterfactual oceanic forcings, i.e. there is no "no climate change" experiment proposed for the fisheries and marine ecosystems sector.
Detrended version of the **obsclim** hourly coastal water levels.
1901 levels ([CO2] = 296.13 ppm) of observed atmospheric CO2 concentrations according to [Meinshausen et al. (2011)](https://doi.org/10.1007/s10584-011-0156-z).
1901 levels of atmospheric CH4 concentrations ([CH4] = 928.8004 ppb), according to [Meinshausen et al. (2017)](https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-10-2057-2017).

climate_scenario.description: Detrended version of the observed climate related forcing used to spin-up the simulations based on a stable 1900 climate
Last 50 years of the splinclim climate forcing data
Climate related input data for the riverine influx sensitivity experiment

harmonization.title: Default
harmonization.description: Model should use their individual “best representation” of the historical period with regard to sowing dates, harvesting dates, fertilizer application rates and crop varieties.

harmonization.title: Fully harmonized
harmonization.description: Simulations based on prescribed “present day” fertilization rates (available for download) and fixed planting and harvesting dates (also available for download). Modelers should have planting as closely as possible to these dates, but it may be admissible to use these dates as indicators for planting windows (depending on model specifics).

harmonization.title: Harmonized seasons with no N constraints
harmonization.description: For models with an explicit description of the nitrogen cycle: harmnon simulations should be run with nitrogen stress turned off completely or (if that’s not possible) with very high N application rates to make model results comparable between those GGCMs that have explicit N dynamics and those that do not. For models without the nitrogen cycle: harmnon and fullharm simulations are the same and do not need to be duplicated. Please contact the sector coordination to push on with this side branch.

soc_dataset.title: Reduced nitrogen deposition
soc_dataset.comment: Simulated by NCAR Chemistry-Climate Model Initiative (CCMI) during 1850-2014 ([Tian et al., 2018](https://doi.org/10.1175/BAMS-D-17-0212.1)). Data for 2015-2021 is assumed to be same as that in 2014. Nitrogen deposition data was interpolated to 0.5° by 0.5° by the nearest grid. For further information refer also to <https://www.isimip.org/gettingstarted/input-data-bias-correction/details/24/>.

Data for 2015-2021 is assumed to be same as that in 2014. Nitrogen deposition data was interpolated to 0.5° by 0.5° by the nearest grid. For further information refer also to <https://www.isimip.org/gettingstarted/input-data-bias-correction/details/24/>.

So far, only a crop calendar, which is static in time is available. It is labeled as 2015soc, but can also be used for histsoc simulations, e.g. in combination with time-varying fertilizer inputs.

variables.long_name: wood harvest area from primary forest land
wood harvest area from primary non forest land

wood harvest area from secondary non forest land

soc_dataset.comment: Historic annual country-level wood harvesting data. Based on the LUH2 v2h Harmonization Data Set ([Hurtt, Chini, Sahajpal, Frolking, et al., 2020](https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-13-5425-2020), see also <https://luh.umd.edu>). Interpolated to a 0.5° grid using first-order conservative remapping and calculated over a fractional country mask (<https://gitlab.pik-potsdam.de/isipedia/countrymasks/-/blob/master/>) derived from [ASAP-GAUL](https://data.europa.eu/euodp/data/dataset/jrc-10112-10004). For further information see <https://www.isimip.org/gettingstarted/input-data-bias-adjustment/details/83/>

soc_dataset.title: Lake area fraction
soc_dataset.comment: Lake and reservoir area fraction/percentage calculated from the Hydrolakes v1.0 June 2019 ([Messager et al., 2016](https://doi.org/10.1038/ncomms13603)) and GRanDv1.3 databases ([Lehner et al., 2011](https://doi.org/10.1890/100125)) mapped to 0.5 degrees resolution, time steps represent increasing reservoirs in their construction year, as given by GRanDv1.3 Reservoirs from 2017 onwards are kept constant. More information about the calculation can be found at <https://github.com/icra/ISIMIP_Lake_Sector>.

soc_dataset.title: Population (gridded)
soc_dataset.comment: Historical population data are based on the 2019 Revision of the United Nations World Population Prospects ([United Nations, 2019](https://population.un.org/wpp/)). For countries not covered by the UNWPP we use data from various sources (e.g. CIA World Factbook, Insee, BEA, PRISM, and Woldometers) compiled in a MissingIslands dataset ([Arujo et al., 2021](https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.4421504)).

soc_dataset.title: Population (country-level)

variables.long_name: total number of people per country

soc_dataset.comment: Historical population data are based on the 2019 Revision of the United Nations World Population Prospects ([United Nations, 2019](https://population.un.org/wpp/)). For countries not covered by the UNWPP we use data from various sources (e.g. CIA World Factbook, Insee, BEA, PRISM, and Woldometers) compiled in a MissingIslands dataset ([Arujo et al., 2021](https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.4421504)).

soc_dataset.title: GDP
soc_dataset.comment: Historic country-level GDP data are based on GDP per capita estimates from the WDI (1965-2020). For countries not covered by the UNWPP we use data from various sources (e.g. CIA World Factbook, Insee, BEA, PRISM, and Woldometers) compiled in a MissingIslands dataset ([Arujo et al., 2021](https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.4421504)).

Source: [Malte Meinshausen et al. (2016)](https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-2016-169) for 1850-2014 and [Ed Dlugokencky (NOAA/GML)](https://gml.noaa.gov/ccgg/trends_ch4/) for 2015-2019.

Source: [Cecil, Daniel J. 2006. LIS/OTD 0.5 Degree High Resolution Monthly Climatology (HRMC)](https://doi.org/10.5067/LIS/LIS-OTD/DATA303). Dataset available online from the NASA Global Hydrology Resource Center DAAC, Huntsville, Alabama, U.S.A.

category.title: Climate related forcing
category.description: Forcing data describing physical or chemical systems, in particular the climate, the oceans, and the cryosphere.

category.title: Static geographic information
category.description: Geographic or other time-independent information, such as land-sea masks, or river routing networks.

category.title: Direct human forcing
category.description: Independent additional forcing data, which influence climate impacts, such as land-use, population or economic changes.

product.title: Input Data
product.description: The data used to drive the impact models, exactly as described in the ISIMIP simulation protocol.

product.title: Secondary Input Data
product.description: Data that have been derived from or are related to the input data, but not described in the simulation protocol (e.g. with a differnt spatial or temporal resolution).

product.title: Output Data
product.description: The climate-impacts simulation data provided by participating modelling groups, corresponding to the output variables described in the ISIMIP simulation protocol.

product.title: Secondary Output Data
product.description: Data that have been derived by processing the ISIMIP output data, but do not correspond to output variables described in the simulation protocol.

variable.comment: Total (surface + subsurface) runoff (qtot = qs + qsb). Please provide both daily and monthly resolution.
Water that leaves the surface layer (top soil layer) e.g. as overland flow / fast runoff.
Sum of water that flows out from subsurface layer(s) including the groundwater layer (if present). Equals qg in case of a groundwater layer below only one soil layer.

For models that consider both diffuse and focussed/localised recharge this should be the sum of both; other models should submit the groundwater recharge component that the model simulates. See also the descriptions in qrf and qrd.
Water that directly flows from a surface water body into the groundwater layer below. Only submit if the model separates focussed/localised recharge from diffuse recharge.

Groundwater recharge from water that enters the groundwater layer via percolation through the soil. Only submit if the model separates focussed/localised recharge from diffuse recharge. For models that do not simulate groundwater this can be seepage instead of recharge.
Water that leaves the groundwater layer. In case seepage is simulated but no groundwater layer is present, report seepage as qr and qg.
River discharge or streamflow. Please provide both daily and monthly resolution.
Sum of transpiration, evaporation, interception and sublimation.
As evap, but with all resistances set to zero, except the aerodynamic resistance.

Please provide soil moisture for all depth layers (i.e. 3D-field), and indicate depth in m. If depth varies over time or space, see instructions for depth layers on <https://www.isimip.org/protocol/preparing-simulation-files>.

Total simulated soil moisture available for evapotranspiration. Please indicate the depth of the root zone for each vegetation type in your model. If depth varies over time or space, see instructions for depth layers on <https://www.isimip.org/protocol/preparing-simulation-files>.
variable.long_name: Soil Moisture Content at Root Zone

variable.comment: Please provide soil moisture for all depth levels and indicate depth in m. See instructions for depth layers on <https://www.isimip.org/protocol/preparing-simulation-files>.

Temperature of each soil layer. Reported as "missing" for grid cells occupied entirely by "sea". If daily resolution not possible, please provide monthly. If depth varies over time or space, see instructions for depth layers on <https://www.isimip.org/protocol/preparing-simulation-files>.
Grid cell mean depth of snowpack.
Total water mass of the snowpack (liquid or frozen) averaged over grid cell.
Mean monthly water storage in all compartments. Please indicate in the netcdf metadata which storage compartments are considered.

Mean monthly water temperature in river (representative of the average temperature across the channel volume).

Irrigation water withdrawn in case of optimal irrigation (i.e. eliminating water stress for the plants). This includes the plant's water requirements over and above precipitation and soil moisture, as well as any losses due to conveyance or irrigation inefficiencies considered.

variable.comment: Soil type as used by your model. Please include a description of each type in the model documentation (under "Other data sets used"). Please also include a link to a database/paper describing the parameters and values associated with these soil types.
Yield may be identical to above-ground biomass (biom) if the entire plant is harvested, e.g. for bioenergy production. Yields are reported per growing seasons and not per year.
Evapotranspiration = sum of transpiration, evaporation, interception and sublimation aggregated across the growing season.

Integral of the total nitrogen application rate over the growing season. If organic and inorganic amendments are applied, the nitrogen application should be reported as effective inorganic nitrogen input (ignoring residues).

As Julian dates. The planting date reported here corresponds to the actual planting date in the simulation and may differ from the prescribed crop calendar planting date in rare cases as certain models may delay prescribed planting for a few days to have more suitable soil moisture and temperature conditions.
Together with the day and year of planting it allows for clear identification of anthesis.
Together with the day and year of planting it allows for clear identification of maturity.
Usually the year when maturity is reached. Can also be computed from planting and maturuty day.
The whole plant biomass above ground.

variable.comment: Soil carbon excluding belowground litter if your model reports clitter. If not including below-ground litter, i.e. only report csoil and document this in the model documentation. Grid cell total and species information is essential.

comment.biomes: Soil carbon excluding belowground litter if your model reports clitter. If not including below-ground litter, i.e. only report csoil and document this in the model documentation. Grid cell total and PFT information is essential. If possible, provide soil carbon for all depth layers (i.e. 3D-field), and indicate depth in m. Otherwise, provide soil carbon integrated over entire soil depth.
comment.fire: Soil carbon excluding belowground litter if your model reports clitter. If not including below-ground litter, i.e. only report csoil and document this in the model documentation. If possible, provide soil carbon for all depth layers (i.e. 3D-field), and indicate depth in m. Otherwise, provide soil carbon integrated over entire soil depth.
comment.forestry: Soil carbon excluding belowground litter if your model reports clitter. If not including below-ground litter, i.e. only report csoil and document this in the model documentation. Grid cell total and species information is essential. If possible, provide soil carbon for all depth layers (i.e. 3D-field), and indicate depth in m. Otherwise, provide soil carbon integrated over entire soil depth.
comment.peat: Soil carbon excluding below-ground litter if your model reports clitterag or clitterbg. If your model does not reports clitterag or clitterbg, report soil carbon including below-ground litter as csoil and document this in the model documentation. Grid cell total and PFT information is essential. If your model simulates soil organic carbon pools of different turnover times, the variable can additionally be provided separated by pools (see note below the table).
comment.permafrost: Soil carbon excluding below-ground litter if your model reports clitterag or clitterbg. If your model does not reports clitterag or clitterbg, report soil carbon including below-ground litter as csoil and document this in the model documentation. Grid cell total and PFT information is essential. If your model simulates soil organic carbon pools of different turnover times, the variable can additionally be provided separated by pools (see note below the table).

geo_dataset.comment: This is the land-sea mask of the W5E5 dataset ([Cucchi et al., 2020](https://doi.org/10.5194/essd-12-2097-2020); [Lange et al., 2021](https://doi.org/10.48364/ISIMIP.342217)). Over all grid cells marked as land by this mask, all climate data that are based on W5E5 (GSWP3-W5E5 as well as climate data bias-adjusted using W5E5) are guaranteed to represent climate conditions over land. For further information see also <https://www.isimip.org/gettingstarted/input-data-bias-adjustment/details/41/>.
Same as **landseamask** but without Antarctica.

This is the generic land-sea mask from ISIMIP2b that is to be used for global water simulations in ISIMIP3. It marks more grid cells as land than **landseamask**. Over those additional land cells, the climate data that are based on W5E5 (GSWP3-W5E5 as well as climate data bias-adjusted using W5E5) are not guaranteed to represent climate conditions over land. Instead they may represent climate conditions over sea or a mix of conditions over land and sea.
Country masks from the ISIpedia project. More formats are available at <https://github.com/ISI-MIP/isipedia-countries>.
Fractional country masks from the ISIpedia project. More formats are available at <https://github.com/ISI-MIP/isipedia-countries>.

geo_dataset.title: Hypsographic: Volume
geo_dataset.comment: Level-Volume Hypsographic curves to be provided to your model (alternatively, you can also use the Level-Volume Hypsographic curves). Each hypsographic consist in 11 data pairs. Level refers to the level of the lake taking the lake bottom as the reference (in meters), Volume is the volume at the corresponding level (in km3). Calculated from GLOBathy, the Global lakes Bathymetry Dataset, January 2022 ([Khazaei et al., 2022](https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.5243309.v1)), and Hydrolakes v1.0 June 2019 ([Messager et al., 2016](https://doi.org/10.1038/ncomms13603>)). More information about the calculation can be found at <https://github.com/icra/ISIMIP_Lake_Sector>.

geo_dataset.title: Hypsographic: Area
geo_dataset.comment: Level-Area Hypsographic curves to be provided to your model (alternatively, you can also use the Level-Volume Hypsographic curves). Each hypsographic consist in 11 data pairs. Level refers to the level of the lake taking the lake bottom as the reference (in meters), Area is the area at the corresponding level (in km2). Calculated from GLOBathy, the Global lakes Bathymetry Dataset, January 2022 ([Khazaei et al., 2022](https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.5243309.v1)), and Hydrolakes v1.0 June 2019 ([Messager et al., 2016](https://doi.org/10.1038/ncomms13603>)). More information about the calculation can be found at <https://github.com/icra/ISIMIP_Lake_Sector>.

geo_dataset.title: Lake Heigth
geo_dataset.comment: Elevation (meters above sea level) for representative lakes calculated from Hydrolakes v1.0 June 2019 ([Messager et al., 2016](https://doi.org/10.1038/ncomms13603)). More information about the calculation can be found at <https://github.com/icra/ISIMIP_Lake_Sector>.

geo_dataset.title: Maximum lake depth
geo_dataset.comment: Maximum depth (meters) for representative lakes calculated from from GLOBathy, the Global lakes Bathymetry Dataset, January 2022 ([Khazaei et al., 2022](https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.5243309.v1)). We recommend using the area or volume hypsographic curves provided in this repository as inputs for your lake model. Use this file only if your lake model does not accept a full hypsographic curve as an input. More information about the calculation can be found at <https://github.com/icra/ISIMIP_Lake_Sector>.

geo_dataset.title: Mean lake depth
geo_dataset.comment: Mean depth (meters) for representative lakes calculated from from GLOBathy, the Global lakes Bathymetry Dataset, January 2022 ([Khazaei et al., 2022](https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.5243309.v1)), and Hydrolakes v1.0 June 2019 ([Messager et al., 2016](https://doi.org/10.1038/ncomms13603)). We recommend using the area or volume hypsographic curves provided in this repository as inputs for your lake model. Use this file only if your lake model does not accept a full hypsographic curve as an input. More information about the calculation can be found at <https://github.com/icra/ISIMIP_Lake_Sector>.

geo_dataset.title: Lake Surface Area

We recommend using the area or volume hypsographic curves as inputs for your lake model. Use this file only if your lake model does not accept a full hypsographic curve as an input. More information about the calculation can be found at <https://github.com/icra/ISIMIP_Lake_Sector>.

We recommend using the area or volume hypsographic curves as inputs for your lake model. Use this file only if your lake model does not accept a full hypsographic curve as an input. climate_forcing.title: GSWP3-W5E5
climate_forcing.comments: Combination of W5E5 v2.0 ([Cucchi et al., 2020](https://doi.org/10.5194/essd-2020-28), and [Lange et al., 2021](https://doi.org/10.48364/ISIMIP.342217)) for 1979-2019 with GSWP3 v1.09 ([Kim, 2017](https://doi.org/10.20783/DIAS.501)) homogenized to W5E5 for 1901-1978. The homogenization reduces discontinuities at the 1978/1979 transition and was done using the ISIMIP3BASD v2.5.0 bias adjustment method ([Lange, 2019](https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-12-3055-2019) and [Lange, 2021](https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.4686991)). For further information see also <https://www.isimip.org/gettingstarted/input-data-bias-adjustment/details/80/>

climate_forcing.title: 20CRv3-W5E5
climate_forcing.comments: Combination of W5E5 v2.0 for 1979-2019 with 20CRv3 (ensemble member 1) homogenized to W5E5 for 1901-1978. The homogenization was done in the same way as for GSWP3-W5E5.

climate_forcing.title: 20CRv3-ERA5
climate_forcing.comments: Combination of ERA5 for 1979-2021 with 20CRv3 (ensemble member 1) homogenized to ERA5 for 1901-1978. The homogenization was done in the same way as for GSWP3-W5E5.

climate_forcing.title: 20CRv3
climate_forcing.comments: Ensemble member 1 of NOAA-CIRES-DOE 20th Century Reanalysis version 3 ([Slivinski et al., 2019](https://doi.org/10.1002/qj.3598) and [Compo et al., 2011](https://doi.org/10.1002/qj.776)) interpolated to 0.5° spatial resolution.

climate_forcing.title: CHELSA-W5E5
climate_forcing.comments: CHELSA-W5E5 v1.0 is a downscaled version of the W5E5 v1.0 dataset, where the downscaling is done with the CHELSA v2.0 algorithm, which applies topographic adjustments based on surface altitude. For the high-resolution sensitivity experiments, this dataset is provided at its original resolution of 30 arcsec as well as in spatially aggregated form, at resolutions of 90 arcsec, 300 arcsec and 1800 arcsec. For more information see [Karger et al. (2022)](https://doi.org/10.48364/ISIMIP.836809.2).

climate_forcing.title: GFDL-MOM6-COBALT2
climate_forcing.comments: JRA-55 driven MOM6-COBALT2 reanalysis. Data on native grid was remapped to a regular 0.25° and 1° grid. For further experiment design details see [Lui et al. (2021)](https://doi.org/10.1029/2021GL094367) and [DOI: 10.48364/ISIMIP.920945](https://doi.org/10.48364/ISIMIP.920945)

Indicates that no bias correction was performed on the climate data (e.g. ocean data).
